brief_description of the content in the: The source URL provides information about a rule that checks for incorrect @Cache* annotation names in Spring Core. It states that at least one cache name should be provided per cache operation: @Cacheable("cache_name") or @Cacheable(cacheNames ="cache_name"). It also mentions that @CacheConfig#cacheNames() can be used for sharing common cache-related settings at the class level.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'incorrect-cache-names-definition' checks all classes in the project. If a class has either the @Cacheable or @CacheConfig annotation, it retrieves the cacheNames attribute from the annotation. It then asserts that the first cache name is not empty. If the assertion fails, it generates a message indicating that the cache name definition in the class is incorrect and that at least one cache name should be provided per cache operation.
